node.title: MPI vs serial displacement results
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I recently added MPI communication to my app and ran a few tests to ensure that my MPI runs deliver the same results as my serial runs. But they didn't. So I started debugging and what I found was that my MPI communication works as intended but MOOSE delivers slightly differing nodal displacements for serial and MPI.
Take the follwing input as an example and run it in serial and then with MPI. The nodal displacements will be very close but not equal. This seems like a minor difference but for my application this error adds up over time which leads to significant differences in my end result.
nx = 2
ny = 2
E0 = 1
nu = 0.3

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]

[Mesh]
  [domain]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmin = -5
    xmax = 5
    ymin = -5
    ymax = 5
    nx = ${nx}
    ny = ${ny}
  []
  [top_right]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    input = domain
    new_boundary = tr
    coord = '5 5 0'
  []
  [bottom_right]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    input = top_right
    new_boundary = br
    coord = '5 -5 0'
  []
  [top_left]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    input = bottom_right
    new_boundary = tl
    coord = '-5 5 0'
  []
  [bottom_left]
    type = ExtraNodesetGenerator
    input = top_left
    new_boundary = bl
    coord = '-5 -5 0'
  []
[]

[Physics]
  [SolidMechanics]
    [QuasiStatic]
      [all]
        strain = SMALL
        add_variables = true
        incremental = false
        generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy stress_xy strain_xx strain_yy strain_xy vonmises_stress'
      []
    []
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [no_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'bl br tl'
    value = 0
  []
  [no_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'bl'
    value = 0
  []
  [disp]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'tl'
    value = 0.5
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = ${E0}
    poissons_ratio = ${nu}
  []
  [compute_stress]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = Newton
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
  [disp_x]
    type = NodalValueSampler
    sort_by = id
    variable = disp_x
    contains_complete_history = true
    execution_order_group = 10
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  csv = true
[]

So my question is: Is this a known effect and if yes what is the reason for the differing displacement results in serial vs MPI?

Hello
The solutions are not exactly the same in serial and parallel because the linear solvers use different preconditioners by default in serial and parallel. The effect is within the solver tolerances (both solutions are converged to tolerances, and the solution should be unique if the problem is well-posed).
If you want the solution to be exactly the same you can look in the PETSc documentation for serial preconditioners like some LU.
I don't know if there are scalable solvers that also give the exact same results in serial
Guillaume

Thank you for your answer.

and the solution should be unique if the problem is well-posed

What do you mean by unique here? What are the criteria to call a solution "unique"? Indentical to the tolerance or completely indentical even at the n-th decimal outside the tolerance?

If you want the solution to be exactly the same you can look in the PETSc documentation for serial preconditioners like some LU.

I'm not sure if understand that correctly. Should the serial and parallel solution be exactly the same when using LU? Because it isn't.

What do you mean by unique here?

Unique in a mathematical way. The finite element approximation of the true solution should be unique with the discretization parameters chosen.

Indentical to the tolerance or completely indentical even at the n-th decimal outside the tolerance?

Close to identical to the tolerance. But there are many caveats. The relative and absolute tolerances behave differently, and the tolerance is in terms of residuals not in terms of how converged each DOFs is.

Should the serial and parallel solution be exactly the same when using LU? Because it isn't.

Should be close given that the preconditioning is supposed to be serial. Maybe not all implementations are serial. You need to look at the PETSc documentation, I don't have all the specs of all PCs in mind

For those which are reading this question. I did it by recompling PetSc, libmesh and wasp but this time id didn't specify the METHODS variable.

I am guessing PETSc built using its own MPI, and libMesh built without MPI, seeing that CC, CXX, etc variables are not set in the diagnostic log.
If you plan on not using our Conda packages, you'll want to satisfy all "FAIL" messages when running ./diagnostic.sh. In your case, you need to specify an MPI wrapper/stack. This normally means setting these variables to mpicc, mpicxx, etc;
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpif90 F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77
./diagnostics.sh
# see if the above worked
This will also mean you'll need to start over (starting with PETSc): All libraries must be compiled using the same compiler stack. e.g everything must be built again after setting CC= CXX= to something it was not beforehand.

node.title: Transferring Temperature data over Time in CSV Using Piecewise Multilinear
node.bodyText: Trying to transfer temperature data for a surface over to MOOSE using Piecewise Multilinear. What values do I use for the nodes for which I do not have temperature data when I'm stepping through the gridded data that I need to write into the data file?

Hello
Whichever value you choose to use you ll have to be careful not to use this part of the domain in your simulation.
If would recommend using a "nearest-valid-value" approach, in which the linear interpolation becomes a constant outside of the known domain
Guillaume
Hmm, so there's no null value that I can throw in there as a placeholder then?
You can try putting a very big number there. I m sure we have some support for NaN too but for this kind of custom behavior you should code your own object

node.title: Clarification on NeckAreaPostprocessor
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE users!
I ran two-particle sintering simulations in a 2D domain and I tried to extend it to a 3D domain. For computational power issues, I considered 2 x 1/32 of particle without modifying any geometric or material-related parameter.
The simulation was successful and, on a graphic level in Paraview, the 2D and 3D solutions coincide. However, when I plotted geometric and energy-related graphs, these are very different from the corresponding case in 2D.
I tried to do some debugging and among the Postprocessors I used, I cannot figure out how NeckAreaPostprocessor operates (and so ElementIntegralVariablePostprocessor), because I don't have much experience.
Thanks!
Simone

Hello
I dont see this object in moose. Are you using the phase field module or are you using an application? if so which one?
Guillaume

Hello
On every Qp it computes this gb quantity.
It looks weird to me, the gb number gets overwritten multiple times in the for loop and only the last value is returned.
@SudiptaBiswas was this intended?

node.title: coupling problem
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I am trying to simulate two different physics with two different input files using phase field module. However, the two different material physics are dependent on each other. Therefore, I am planning to do a coupled simulation. The computation will look like:

First run input1.i file to solve the first physics and get the output file (input1.e) with grain structure and grain boundaries.
Next, import the grain structure and boundaries from input1.e file to input2.i file and solve the second physics. Get the input2.e file from this step with output grain structure and grain boundaries.
Following that feed the grain structure and grain boundaries from input2.e file in the input1.i file and solve the first physics again.

These simulation steps will repeat for a certain time.
Would you be kind to let me know, how to do such computation in MOOSE? Do I need to use a Multiapp system for that? If so which Multiapp system will be the most appropriate for these problem?
I would appreciate your advice.
Thanks, and best regards,
Zahid

Hi,
I would suggest "TransientMultiApp', you can control the apps via "execute_on" and "sub_cycling".
OR
Another option would be to apply "restart" to feed the parent/child at each step by child/parent output.
Rahim

@Rahim-Habibi Dear Rahim, since I am exchanging the grain structure and grain boundaries between two simulations, do you think the following input in the parent file makes sense for a TransientMultiApp:
"[MultiApps]
[sub]
type = TransientMultiApp
app_type = MooseTestApp
positions = '0 0 0'
input_files = 'recr-test-2.i'
clone_parent_mesh = true
execute_on = 'timestep_end'
[]
[]
[Transfers]
[bnds_from_sub]
type = MultiAppShapeEvaluationTransfer
from_multi_app = sub
source_variable = bnds
variable = bnds
execute_on = 'timestep_end'
[]
[gr0_from_sub]
type = MultiAppShapeEvaluationTransfer
from_multi_app = sub
source_variable = gr0
variable = gr0
execute_on = 'timestep_end'
[]
[bnds_to_sub]
type = MultiAppShapeEvaluationTransfer
to_multi_app = sub
source_variable = bnds
variable = bnds
execute_on = 'timestep_end'
[]
[gr0_to_sub]
type = MultiAppShapeEvaluationTransfer
to_multi_app = sub
source_variable = gr0
variable = gr0
execute_on = 'timestep_end'
[]
[]"
Other queries:
I am using the identical computational domain and scale for both simulations. Therefore, positions = '0 0 0' is correct? If clone_parent_mesh = true, will the second.i use the output mesh from the first.i?
Thanks, and best regards,
Zahid

Hi,
Yes, it seems OK.
Regarding your second query, "clone_parent_mesh" is about the mesh and initilizes the apps by same mesh when it is true.  Generally you can define the mesh either in child app or parant app using this option.
When you want to run child app in spacfic position(s) you need to set position otherwise just leave the setting as it is (I think so).
To have control on the outputs, check "Transfers" objects and use the proper one based on your problem.
Rahim

Hello
Is this a transient and you are solving physics1 then physics2 every time step?
In this case use a TransientMultiapp
Or are you looking for a steady state equilibrium solution?
In this case use a FullSolveMultiapp
You can use Transfers to pass the solution between the two solves
There is a tutorial on this here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/tutorial02_multiapps/presentation/index.html#/
Guillaume
@GiudGiud Appreciate.

node.title: Multiple Cubes with Mesh Generation
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am trying to simulate the thermal expansion of two copper wafers using MOOSE and visualizing on Paraview. I am struggling to create 2 objects in moose. I am using the solid_mechanics/thermal_expansion/constant_expansion_stress_free_temp.i
This is what I have, I just want to make 2 cubes and see both of them expand and come in contact.
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 3
  nx = 2
  ny = 2
  nz = 2
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./temp]
  [../]
[]

[Functions]
  [./temperature_load]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = t*(500.0)+300.0
  [../]
[]

[Physics]
  [SolidMechanics]
    [QuasiStatic]
      [./all]
        strain = SMALL
        incremental = true
        add_variables = true
        eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain
        generate_output = 'strain_xx strain_yy strain_zz'
      [../]
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./tempfuncaux]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = temp
    function = temperature_load
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./x_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = left
    value = 0.0
  [../]
  [./y_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0.0
  [../]
  [./z_bot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = back
    value = 0.0
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 2.1e5
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
  [../]
  [./small_stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  [../]
  [./thermal_expansion_strain]
    type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    stress_free_temperature = 298
    thermal_expansion_coeff = 1.3e-5
    temperature = temp
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'

  l_max_its = 50
  nl_max_its = 50
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-12
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
  l_tol = 1e-9

  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 0.075
  dt = 0.0125
  dtmin = 0.0001
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  checkpoint = true
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./strain_xx]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = strain_xx
  [../]
  [./strain_yy]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = strain_yy
  [../]
  [./strain_zz]
    type = ElementAverageValue
    variable = strain_zz
  [../]
  [./temperature]
    type = AverageNodalVariableValue
    variable = temp
  [../]
[]

Hello
Try this to make two cubes
[Mesh]
  [cube1]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    nx = 2
    ny = 2
    nz = 2
    subdomain_name = 'cube1'
  []
  [cube2]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    xmin = 1
    xmax = 2
    nx = 2
    ny = 2
    nz = 2
    subdomain_ids = '1'
    subdomain_name = 'cube2'
  []
  [stitch]
    type = StitchedMeshGenerator
    inputs = 'cube1 cube2'
    stitch_boundaries_pairs = 'right left'
[]
[]

The two meshes will have different subdomains so you can define different materials on them for example

Awesome, that worked. Thanks!
The only issue I'm having now is that whenever I take the file to paraview (visualizer for moose), it's not able to create the cubes as it was able to before with just the 1.

also, after the 3rd time step, in the ran test,
30 Linear |R| = 6.013082e-14
this is red, while all the other are green.
the 30th is red because the residual increased instead of decreased. this is not cause for concern
in StitchedMeshGenerator set prevent_boundary_ids_overlap = False

Wow, thanks. That worked. Do you mind explaining the syntax of the coordinate system? I am now trying to create a small gap between those two cubes instead of having them touch so I can see at what distance I can set them apart so they come in contact under increase in temp.

if the cubes should be separate do not stitch them
you can use a CombinerGenerator to just have the two blocks sitting next to each other

Ok.

Also, on a separate note. If I want to change the material of the cube, how would I do that? Is that something I need to do in moose or in paraview?
Is it possible to have a cube and a cylinder together as well instead of 2 cubes?

these are both trivial things to do in moose
please follow the training material here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/index.html

I was able to create the Concentric circle but I can't get the extrude generator to work.
[Mesh]
[cube1]
type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
dim = 3
nx = 2
ny = 2
nz = 2
subdomain_name = 'cube1'
[]
[circle]
type = ConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
num_sectors = 6
radii = '0.2546 0.3368 0.3600 0.3818 0.3923 0.4025 0.4110 0.4750'
rings = '5 3 2 1 1 1 1 3 5'
has_outer_square = on
pitch = 1.42063
#portion = left_half
preserve_volumes = off
smoothing_max_it = 3
[]
[extrude]
type = AdvancedExtruderGenerator
input = cylinder
heights = '1 2 3'
num_layers = '1 2 3'
direction = '0 0 1'
bottom_sideset = '4'
top_sideset = '5'
subdomain_swaps = '0 1;
0 2;
0 3'
[]
[stitch]
type = StitchedMeshGenerator
prevent_boundary_ids_overlap = False
inputs = 'cube1 cylinder'
stitch_boundaries_pairs = 'right left'
[]
[]
*** ERROR ***
Your MeshGenerator tree contains multiple possible generator outputs :
"stitch and one or more of the following from an independent set: "extrude"
This may be due to a missing dependency or may be intentional. Please either

check that all the mesh generators are connected as a tree and culminate in a single final mesh. Having one wrong 'input=mg' parameter is the most common error
add additional dependencies to remove the ambiguity if you are using a user-built MeshGenerator
if you intend to execute a subset of the defined generators (uncommon), select the final MeshGenerator in the [Mesh] block with the "final_generator" parameter.

the error message explains what is happening.
you need every mesh generator to form a connected graph with a single output mesh (the tree)

node.title: Switching from constant rate well to constant BHP
node.bodyText: Is there currently a way to switch from a constant rate well to a constant bottomhole pressure (BHP) well once a certain max BHP is reached?
Is there a way to combine the current DiracKernels or PorousFlowSinks like the PeacemanBorehole to mimic this constraint?
@cpgr

Not at the moment I don't believe. You could perhaps use the controls system and a function based on a post processor for bottom hole pressure to turn off a constant rate source and turn on a Peaceman source?
